posts.post_content:
One synergy this card has is with [pyromancer ascension](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=pyromancer ascension). If you have pyromancer on the board, when you cast a sorcery and spellweaver volute triggers, since you *cast* a *copy* of the card in the graveyard, you get a counter on the ascension even if the enchanted instant is the only one you have in your graveyard.   
  
For example, you have 1 lightening bolt in your graveyard, enchanted by volute, with the ascension on your side of the board. You cast fireball, the volute triggers the lightening bolt to cast, you get a counter on the ascension.

posts.post_content:
The good thing about it is that you can attach it to an instant card in any graveyard. However, one should never assume the opponent is going to have any instants worth copying when compared to the ones you own.   
  
The problem comes from the fact that you should have an even distribution of both sorceries and instants in your deck to make this card productive. Even then, having more than two in the deck is too much, as one in play should be well enough to suit your needs.  
  
The mana cost is too high - at five mana you would probably be able to play a card that would yield a similar effect as all the cards in your graveyard that would eventually be copied. Perhaps this could see some action in casual decks, but in competitive play one must not waste turns to prepare for something that could possibly result in no effect whatsoever. Who guarantees there's even going to be both an instant card in a graveyard and a sorcery in your hand as you draw it? This card is way too random.

I think this card got a low rating because many newer players simply have absolutely no idea how it works or how to make good use of it.  
  
It's best in sorcery heavy multiplayer decks. I run it in Commander decks, especially those using many sorceries with flashback, rebound, buyback or retrace, since I can that way keep triggering the volute over and over, playing instants from other peoples graveyards.  
It's even better when you have [vedalken orrery](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=vedalken orrery) or something similiar in play, since you can then play sorceries at instant speed, and thus even make use of counterspells people have played.  
  
 I mean, come on:   
- it let's you play other peoples spells (already good),  
- without paying their casting cost (better)  
- without the volute having an activation cost once in play (!)  
- do that not just once but as often as there are instants in graveyards and you have sorceries to play  
- and it messes up peoples graveyards, interrupting their recursion combos
